Comment: Just so people are aware…. This is not just the fund that gets narcan into the hands of first responders. It’s the one that gets pain patients free doses with their prescriptions, and also allows hospitals to give out doses to “frequent flyers” or anyone who asks for it in the ER. The simple act of handing out free narcan at my own ER has probably saved more lives than I actually have in my career. This is a stupid move and it’s done purely to “weed out undesirables” just like much of the flaccid cheetos policies are.

Comment: That’s a pretty awful and callous statement. For shame. There has always been a prevailing belief in civilized society, religion and just ethics that all life has value. Those who don’t seem have any value at the given moment are still deserving of life. Don’t also confuse being unwilling with unable when it comes to “helping themselves”. Many people with addiction disorders have other untreated factors that are driving their behavior such as untreated mental disorders. Many people who are addicted to opioids even got their start from a legitimate prescription based on lies from a pharmaceutical company. Have you ever had a time when you needed a helping hand? Did you ever have a friend or family member help you through a hard time in your life? If you can honestly say no to that you’re lucky…but most of us have. You’re also forgetting that our taxes pay for a lot of things we don’t get to use personally. Maybe you don’t need Narcan, but have you ever been on food stamps? Did you get a PPP loan? Have you ridden the bus? Did a firefighter help you out during a car crash?  Do you attend a public university?Just because you personally don’t need a government service at any given time doesn’t mean it’s not worthwhile.
